meanings.definition: To officially declare someone as a saint in the Roman Catholic Church.
meanings.sent1: The Pope will canonise Mother Teresa for her selfless work.
meanings.sent2: The process to canonise a saint involves thorough investigation and miracles.
meanings.sent3: Imagine if they tried to canonise a mischievous squirrel as a saint!
meanings.sent4: Her kindness and generosity canonise her as an angel among us.
meanings.sent5: The ceremony to canonise a saint is a solemn and revered event.

meanings.definition: To include a literary work in the canon of great literature.
meanings.sent1: Shakespeare's plays are canonised as timeless classics.
meanings.sent2: Authors aspire to have their works canonised alongside the literary giants.
meanings.sent3: In a world where cats write novels, would they canonise tales of mice triumphing?
meanings.sent4: The impact of his poetry canonises it as a masterpiece of the era.
meanings.sent5: To canonise a book is to immortalize its significance in the literary world.

meanings.definition: To establish rules or principles as authoritative or accepted.
meanings.sent1: The committee will canonise the new regulations for the organization.
meanings.sent2: It is important to canonise ethical guidelines to ensure fair practices.
meanings.sent3: If we canonise the rule of wearing hats on Tuesdays, chaos may ensue!
meanings.sent4: The tradition of handshake to seal a deal canonises trust in business.
meanings.sent5: To canonise a principle is to give it the stamp of approval and respect.
